name: Roee Ozeri

postdocs.institution: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Boulder

thesis.note: Thesis title/PDF not found in open-access sources; may be available via Weizmann library or by request.

short_bio: Prof. Roee Ozeri is an experimental physicist working in atomic physics and quantum information science. He earned a BSc in Physics from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem and completed his MSc and PhD in Physics at the Weizmann Institute of Science under Prof. Nir Davidson.

name: Ziv Meir

postdocs.note: Postdoctoral continuation inferred from 2017–2018 Weizmann-affiliated atom–ion publications with Ozeri-group coauthors; official bios do not explicitly name a PI.

thesis.title: Dynamics of a single, ground-state cooled and trapped ion colliding with ultracold atoms: A micromotion tale

short_bio: Dr. Ziv Meir is an experimental physicist and principal investigator at the Weizmann Institute of Science. His research develops quantum-logic techniques—originally created for trapped-ion quantum computing and optical clocks—to control, detect, and manipulate single trapped molecular ions, enabling “molecular qubits” and new precision spectroscopy capabilities.

name: Chris Ballance
short_bio: Dr. Chris Ballance is a physicist and quantum-technology leader working on trapped-ion quantum computing across academia and industry. He completed his DPhil (PhD) at the University of Oxford under Prof. David M. Lucas, with a thesis on high-fidelity trapped-ion quantum logic.

name: Christopher R. Monroe

current_position.title: Gilhuly Family Presidential Distinguished Professor (Physics & ECE)

education.note: Advisor confirmed by multiple bios; Eric Cornell is also cited as a key collaborator during the PhD period.

postdocs.institution: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Boulder

thesis.note: Thesis title not found in open-access sources; may exist in ProQuest/University library catalog.

short_bio: Christopher R. Monroe is a physicist and a leading figure in trapped-ion quantum information science. He is the Gilhuly Family Presidential Distinguished Professor of Electrical & Computer Engineering and Physics at Duke University, and a co-founder of IonQ, a company commercializing trapped-ion quantum computers.

name: Christian F. Roos

thesis.title: Controlling the quantum state of trapped ions

short_bio: Dr. Christian F. Roos is an experimental physicist working on trapped-ion quantum science, including quantum simulation and precision spectroscopy. He is affiliated with IQOQI Innsbruck (Austrian Academy of Sciences) and the University of Innsbruck.

name: David J. Wineland

current_position.title: Philip H. Knight Distinguished Research Chair; Research Professor (Physics)

short_bio: David J. Wineland is a Nobel Prize–winning experimental physicist known for pioneering techniques to **trap, laser-cool, and coherently control single ions**, enabling major advances in **precision atomic clocks** and **trapped-ion quantum information processing**. He spent decades at NIST (Boulder), where his group developed foundational methods for high-fidelity quantum logic with ions, and later joined the University of Oregon as a Research Professor.

name: Dietrich Leibfried

current_position.institution: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Boulder
current_position.title: Fellow / Group Lead (Ion Storage / Trapped-Ion Quantum Science)

education.note: Thesis research conducted at Max Planck Institute for Quantum Optics (MPQ).

short_bio: Dietrich Leibfried is a leading experimental physicist in trapped-ion quantum information science at NIST (Boulder). His work spans high-fidelity trapped-ion operations, quantum control, quantum networking, and precision spectroscopy.

name: John J. Bollinger

current_position.institution: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Boulder
current_position.title: Staff Scientist / Group Lead (Ion Storage Group)

thesis.title: Measurement of the 42S1/2-42P1/2 Lamb Shift in He+

short_bio: John J. Bollinger is a senior experimental physicist at NIST (Boulder) known for work on Penning-trap ion crystals, precision measurement, and strongly-coupled many-body dynamics in trapped-ion systems.

name: Hartmut Häffner

education.note: Advisor inferred from publications (e.g. PRL 85, 5304) and shared affiliation at Mainz; needs independent confirmation.

thesis.title: High-accuracy measurement of the magnetic moment anomaly of the electron bound in hydrogenlike carbon

short_bio: Hartmut Häffner is a professor at UC Berkeley working on trapped-ion quantum science and precision measurement, with interests including reducing surface noise and developing novel trapped-particle platforms.

name: Jungsang Kim

thesis.note: Thesis title inferred from doctoral research focus; exact title not confirmed in open-access sources.
thesis.title: Generation and detection of single photon states

short_bio: Jungsang Kim is a professor at Duke University working on trapped-ion quantum information systems, with strong emphasis on engineering and integration: microfabricated traps, photonics, detectors, compact cryo/vacuum, and system-scale architectures.

name: Kihwan Kim

current_position.institution: Institute for Basic Science (IBS), South Korea
current_position.title: Professor / Group Leader (Trapped-Ion Quantum Science)

thesis.note: Thesis title not found in open-access sources; PhD year confirmed from biographical sources.

short_bio: Kihwan Kim is a leading trapped-ion quantum computing experimentalist known for high-fidelity control, multi-qubit entangling operations, and quantum simulation with ions. Recent reporting indicates a move from Tsinghua University to South Korea to lead a new IBS trapped-ion research group.

name: Winfried K. Hensinger

education.advisor: Halina Rubinsztein-Dunlop; Norman Heckenberg; Gerard Milburn

thesis.title: Experimental nonlinear quantum dynamics with ultracold atoms

short_bio: Winfried K. Hensinger is a professor at the University of Sussex leading research toward scalable trapped-ion quantum computing, including architectures designed around microwave control and engineering-driven modularity.

name: Ferdinand Schmidt-Kaler

thesis.note: German title: High-resolution spectroscopy of the 1S-2S transition in a cold hydrogen and deuterium atomic beam
thesis.title: Hochauflösende Spektroskopie des 1S-2S Übergangs in einem kalten Wasserstoff- und Deuterium-Atomstrahl

short_bio: Ferdinand Schmidt-Kaler is a professor at Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz working on trapped-ion quantum computing, including segmented-trap technologies, architectures, and improving coherence and gate performance in scalable systems.

name: Thomas Monz

thesis.title: Quantum information processing beyond ten ion-qubits

short_bio: Thomas Monz is an experimental quantum physicist at the University of Innsbruck and a founder of Alpine Quantum Technologies (AQT). His work spans trapped-ion quantum computing, quantum algorithms, and system-level validation, with earlier work also touching ion–photon interfaces and precision spectroscopy.

name: Tracy E. Northup

education.note: Thesis title appears in open sources; PDF may be via library/catalog.

thesis.title: Coherent control in cavity QED
thesis.note: WorldCat catalog link; PDF availability depends on library access.

short_bio: Tracy E. Northup is a professor at the University of Innsbruck working on quantum interfaces between light and matter, especially trapped ions coupled to optical cavities, with applications to quantum networking and quantum-enabled sensing.

name: Jonathan P. Home
short_bio: Jonathan P. Home is a professor at ETH Zürich and leads research in trapped-ion quantum information processing, with a focus on precision control, error correction, and scalable architectures (including integrated trap technologies).

name: Rainer Blatt

current_position.title: Professor (Experimental Physics); Research Director (IQOQI Innsbruck, ÖAW)

thesis.note: Thesis title/PDF not located in open-access sources yet; CV confirms doctorate at University of Mainz and association with Günter Werth.

short_bio: Rainer Blatt is an experimental physicist who helped establish **trapped ions** as a leading platform for **quantum information processing**, **quantum simulation**, and **precision measurement**. He is a Professor at the University of Innsbruck and a Research Director at IQOQI Innsbruck (ÖAW), and he is a co-founder of Alpine Quantum Technologies (AQT), a trapped-ion quantum computing company spun out from Innsbruck.

name: Michael Drewsen

education.note: Spent 10 months at l'Ecole Normale Supérieure in Paris with C. Cohen-Tannoudji during PhD

short_bio: Michael Drewsen is a professor at Aarhus University and leads research in trapped-ion physics, with particular focus on molecular ions, Coulomb crystals, and quantum simulation. His group has made significant contributions to sympathetic cooling techniques and precision spectroscopy of molecular ions.

name: Michael Köhl
short_bio: Michael Köhl is a professor at the University of Bonn leading research in experimental quantum physics with trapped ions. His group focuses on quantum communication nodes using trapped Ytterbium ions coupled to optical cavities, developing quantum networks and exploring quantum information processing with fiber-based systems.

name: Luming Duan

current_position.title: Yao Qizhi Chair Professor / Chair Professor of Basic Sciences

short_bio: Luming Duan is a Yao Qizhi Chair Professor at Tsinghua University's Institute for Interdisciplinary Information Sciences (IIIS) and an Academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. His group has achieved major breakthroughs in trapped-ion quantum simulation, including stable trapping of up to 512 ions and quantum simulations with 300 ion qubits—the largest-scale multi-ion quantum simulation with single-qubit resolution to date. He is known for the DLCZ protocol for long-distance quantum communication.

name: Michael J. Biercuk
short_bio: Michael J. Biercuk is a quantum physicist and Director of the Quantum Control Laboratory at the University of Sydney. He is also the founder and CEO of Q-CTRL, a quantum technology company. His research focuses on quantum control techniques for trapped ions, quantum error suppression, and developing practical quantum technologies.

name: K. Rajibul Islam

current_position.institution: Institute for Quantum Computing, University of Waterloo
current_position.title: Associate Professor

thesis.title: Quantum Simulation of Interacting Spin Models with Trapped Ions

short_bio: K. Rajibul Islam is an Associate Professor at the Institute for Quantum Computing (IQC) and the Department of Physics and Astronomy at the University of Waterloo. His research focuses on experimental quantum many-body physics, particularly quantum simulation of frustrated spin models with trapped ions. He leads the Laboratory for Quantum Information with Trapped Ions (QITI) and co-founded Open Quantum Design, offering the world's first open-source, full-stack trapped-ion quantum computer.

name: Crystal Senko

current_position.institution: Institute for Quantum Computing, University of Waterloo
current_position.title: Associate Professor / Canada Research Chair in Trapped Ion Quantum Computing

short_bio: Crystal Senko is an Assistant Professor at the Institute for Quantum Computing (IQC) at the University of Waterloo. Her research focuses on trapped-ion quantum simulation and quantum computing. She co-founded Open Quantum Design alongside Rajibul Islam, Roger Melko, and Greg Dick, creating the world's first open-source, full-stack trapped-ion quantum computer.

name: Paul Haljan
short_bio: Paul Haljan is an Associate Professor of Physics at Simon Fraser University, where he leads the Trapped Ion Quantum Technology Lab. His research focuses on trapped-ion quantum technologies, including scalable quantum computing with cadmium and ytterbium ions, microstructure development for ion trap designs, and high-fidelity entanglement operations.

name: Christian Schmiegelow
short_bio: Christian Schmiegelow leads the Laboratory of Cold Ions and Atoms at the University of Buenos Aires, Argentina. His research focuses on trapped-ion quantum optics and quantum information processing, representing a key center for ion trapping research in South America.

name: Erik W. Streed

current_position.title: Associate Professor / Director, Queensland Quantum and Advanced Technologies Research Institute

short_bio: Erik W. Streed is an Associate Professor at Griffith University and Director of the Queensland Quantum and Advanced Technologies Research Institute. His research applies quantum physics techniques with trapped ions to biological challenges, exploring biomolecular dynamics through ion trapping and advanced microscopy. He also investigates light transmission for quantum computing using segmented optics.

name: Lukáš Slodička

education.note: Dissertation on single ion-single photon interactions in free space

thesis.title: Single ion - single photon interactions in free space

short_bio: Lukáš Slodička leads the Trapped Ions group in the Department of Optics at Palacký University Olomouc, Czech Republic. His research focuses on quantum optics with trapped ions, particularly atom-light interactions and efficient ion-photon interfaces. He completed his PhD at the University of Innsbruck, working on trapped ion crystals for quantum bit implementation.

name: Jürgen Eschner

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Jürgen Eschner leads the Quantum Photonics Group at Saarland University, focusing on trapped-ion quantum information processing with calcium ions, quantum networks, and atom-photon interfaces.

name: Christof Wunderlich

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Christof Wunderlich leads the Quantum Optics Research Group at the University of Siegen. His group is known for pioneering work on microwave-driven quantum logic with trapped ytterbium ions and magnetic gradient traps for quantum information processing.

name: Rene Gerritsma

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Rene Gerritsma leads research on Hybrid Atom-Ion Quantum Systems at the University of Amsterdam. His group explores the interface between ultracold neutral atoms and trapped ions for quantum simulation and quantum information applications.

name: Jeroen C. J. Koelemeij

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Jeroen C. J. Koelemeij leads the HD+ spectroscopy team at VU Amsterdam. His research focuses on precision spectroscopy of molecular hydrogen ions (HD+) for tests of fundamental physics and determination of fundamental constants.

name: Murray D. Barrett

current_position.institution: Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore
current_position.title: Principal Investigator

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Murray D. Barrett leads the Microtraps Group at the Centre for Quantum Technologies (CQT) in Singapore. His research focuses on developing microfabricated ion traps for scalable quantum computing and quantum networking with barium and lutetium ions.

name: Dzmitry Matsukevich

current_position.institution: Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore
current_position.title: Principal Investigator

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Dzmitry Matsukevich leads research on trapped molecular ions at the Centre for Quantum Technologies (CQT) in Singapore. His group works on quantum networking and quantum communication using ytterbium and molecular ions (SiO+), focusing on ion-photon entanglement.

name: Manas Mukherjee

current_position.institution: Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore
current_position.title: Principal Investigator

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Manas Mukherjee leads the Cold Ion Group at the Centre for Quantum Technologies (CQT) in Singapore. His research focuses on trapped-ion quantum computing and quantum simulation with barium ions.

name: Stefan Willitsch

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Stefan Willitsch leads the Willitsch Group at the University of Basel. His research focuses on trapped molecular ions, ion-molecule reactions at ultracold temperatures, and applications of trapped ions to quantum chemistry and chemical physics.

name: Richard C. Thompson

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Richard C. Thompson leads the Ion Trapping Group at Imperial College London. His group has been a long-established center for trapped-ion quantum information research, working with calcium ions on quantum computing and fundamental ion trap technology.

name: David M. Lucas

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: David M. Lucas leads the Ion Trap Quantum Computing Group at the University of Oxford alongside Andrew Steane. The Oxford group is one of the world's leading centers for trapped-ion quantum computing, working with calcium and strontium ions on quantum error correction, high-fidelity quantum gates, and optical clocks.

name: Eric R. Hudson

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Eric R. Hudson leads the Hudson Lab at UCLA, focusing on trapped molecular ions, ultracold chemistry, and quantum simulation. His group works with barium, ytterbium, and molecular ions to explore ion-neutral collisions and chemical reactions at ultracold temperatures.

name: Wesley C. Campbell

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Wesley C. Campbell leads the Campbell Lab at UCLA, focusing on trapped-ion quantum simulation and quantum computing with ytterbium ions. His research also includes precision measurement and optical atomic clocks.

name: Vladan Vuletić

thesis.note: Thesis title not found in CV snippet provided; add once verified from an institutional thesis repository or catalog.

short_bio: Vladan Vuletić is the Lester Wolfe Professor of Physics at MIT. His research focuses on ultracold atoms, quantum optics, and quantum information processing. He is also a co-founder and the Chief Technology Officer (CTO) of QuEra Computing Inc., a company developing neutral-atom quantum computers.

name: Isaac L. Chuang

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Isaac L. Chuang leads the Quanta Group at MIT's Center for Ultracold Atoms. A pioneer in quantum computing, his research includes trapped-ion quantum information processing with strontium ions, quantum algorithms, and quantum error correction.

name: Kenneth R. Brown

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Kenneth R. Brown leads a major trapped-ion quantum computing group at Duke University. His research focuses on quantum error correction, fault-tolerant quantum computing, and quantum control with calcium, ytterbium, and boron ions.

name: Kilian Singer

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Kilian Singer leads the Trapped Ion Quantum Information and Thermodynamics group at the University of Kassel. His research focuses on single-ion heat engines, thermodynamics in the quantum regime, and scalable ion trap technologies.

name: Johannes Hecker Denschlag

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Johannes Hecker Denschlag leads the Institute for Quantum Matter at Ulm University. His group investigates ultracold quantum gases and hybrid systems of trapped ions and neutral atoms (Ba+ and Rb), focusing on cold collisions and quantum chemistry.

name: Kazuhiro Hayasaka

current_position.institution: National Institute of Information and Communications Technology (NICT)
current_position.title: Group Leader

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Kazuhiro Hayasaka leads the Space-Time Standards Laboratory at NICT in Kobe, Japan. His research focuses on developing high-precision optical clocks using trapped indium and calcium ions for frequency standards and metrology.

name: Kjeld S. E. Eikema

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Kjeld S. E. Eikema leads the Ultrafast Laser Physics and Precision Metrology group at VU Amsterdam. His research combines frequency combs with trapped ions for extreme precision measurements and tests of fundamental physics.

name: Klaus Jungmann

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Klaus Jungmann leads the Fundamental Interactions and Symmetries group at the University of Groningen. His prominent work involves precision measurements with trapped radium ions to test fundamental symmetries and search for physics beyond the Standard Model.

name: Hermann Uys

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Hermann Uys leads the trapped ion research group at Stellenbosch University and the CSIR in South Africa. His work focuses on trapped ytterbium ions for quantum control, simulation of many-body physics, and quantum thermodynamics.

name: Patrick Gill

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Patrick Gill co-leads the Time & Frequency department at NPL. He is a world-leading pioneer in optical frequency standards and trapped-ion optical clocks, particularly using strontium and ytterbium ions for high-precision metrology.

name: Rachel Godun

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Rachel Godun leads the Ytterbium Ion Optical Clock team at the National Physical Laboratory (NPL). Her research focuses on developing and improving trapped-ion optical clocks for next-generation timekeeping and fundamental physics tests.

name: John Chiaverini

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: John Chiaverini leads trapped-ion research at MIT Lincoln Laboratory. His work focuses on scalable quantum computing architectures, integrated photonics for ion traps, and surface-electrode trap technology.

name: Dan Stick

education.note: PhD details require verification from institutional sources

short_bio: Dan Stick leads the trapped ion trap fabrication and testing efforts at Sandia National Laboratories. His High Optical Access (HOA) surface traps are widely used in the community, and his research focuses on integrating optics and improving trap technologies for quantum computing.

name: Masao Kitano
short_bio: Masao Kitano leads research in quantum optics and trapped-ion systems at Kyoto University. His work focuses on quantum information processing with ytterbium ions.

name: Hiroki Takahashi

current_position.institution: Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology (OIST)
current_position.title: Associate Professor

short_bio: Hiroki Takahashi leads the Quantum Systems Unit at OIST. His research focuses on trapped-ion quantum networks and cavity QED with calcium and barium ions.

name: Takashi Mukaiyama
short_bio: Takashi Mukaiyama leads ion trap research at Osaka University focusing on quantum logic spectroscopy and optical clock development with calcium and indium ions.

name: Kenji Toyoda
short_bio: Kenji Toyoda conducts trapped-ion research at Osaka University focusing on quantum simulation and quantum computing with calcium ions.

name: Utako Tanaka
short_bio: Utako Tanaka conducts trapped-ion research at Osaka University focusing on microfabricated ion traps and quantum computing with calcium ions.

name: Atsushi Noguchi
short_bio: Atsushi Noguchi leads research at the University of Tokyo on hybrid quantum systems combining trapped beryllium ions with superconducting circuits.

name: Shuichi Hasegawa
short_bio: Shuichi Hasegawa leads trapped-ion research at the University of Tokyo focusing on laser cooling and quantum control with calcium ions.

name: Moonjoo Lee
short_bio: Moonjoo Lee leads the trapped-ion quantum computing group at POSTECH (Pohang University of Science and Technology). His research focuses on quantum simulation and computing with ytterbium ions.

name: Taeyoung Choi
short_bio: Taeyoung Choi leads trapped-ion research at Ewha Womans University in Seoul, focusing on quantum computing and quantum control with ytterbium ions.

name: Dan Cho
short_bio: Dan Cho leads trapped-ion research at Seoul National University focusing on quantum information processing with ytterbium ions.

name: Taehyun Kim
short_bio: Taehyun Kim leads trapped-ion research at Seoul National University focusing on quantum computing and quantum networks with ytterbium ions.

name: Junki Kim
short_bio: Junki Kim leads trapped-ion research at Sungkyunkwan University (SKKU) focusing on quantum computing and simulation with ytterbium and barium ions.

name: Kihwan Kim

current_position.institution: University of Science and Technology of China (USTC)
current_position.title: Professor

short_bio: Kihwan Kim leads a major trapped-ion quantum computing group at USTC in Hefei, China. His research focuses on large-scale quantum simulation and computing with ytterbium and barium ions.

name: Luyan Sun
short_bio: Luyan Sun leads quantum information research at Tsinghua University focusing on hybrid quantum systems and trapped-ion quantum computing.

name: Wenhui Li
short_bio: Wenhui Li leads research at Peking University on trapped ions and Rydberg atoms for quantum simulation and computing.

name: Mirko Lobino
short_bio: Mirko Lobino leads quantum photonics and trapped-ion research at Griffith University in Brisbane, Australia, focusing on hybrid quantum systems.

name: Michael J. Biercuk
short_bio: Michael J. Biercuk leads the Quantum Control Laboratory at the University of Sydney and is a founder of Q-CTRL. His research focuses on quantum control techniques for trapped ytterbium ions.

name: Rajibul Islam
short_bio: Rajibul Islam leads the Quantum Many-Body Physics Lab at the University of Waterloo and Institute for Quantum Computing (IQC). His research focuses on quantum simulation with trapped ytterbium ions.

name: Paul Barclay
short_bio: Paul Barclay leads quantum photonics research at Simon Fraser University focusing on hybrid quantum systems and diamond-based quantum technologies.

name: S. A. Rangwala

current_position.institution: Indian Institute of Science Education and Research (IISER) Pune
current_position.title: Professor

short_bio: S. A. Rangwala leads cold atoms and ions research at Raman Research Institute/IISER Pune, focusing on hybrid ion-atom systems and cold collisions.

name: Michael Drewsen
short_bio: Michael Drewsen leads the Ion Trap Group at Aarhus University, pioneering work on large ion Coulomb crystals, sympathetic cooling, and molecular ion spectroscopy.

name: Markus Hennrich
short_bio: Markus Hennrich leads the Trapped Rydberg Ion Group at Stockholm University, pioneering work on Rydberg excitation of trapped ions for quantum computing.

name: Winfried K. Hensinger
short_bio: Winfried K. Hensinger leads the Sussex Ion Quantum Technology group, developing scalable trapped-ion quantum computing architectures using microwave-driven gates.

name: Matthias Keller
short_bio: Matthias Keller leads trapped-ion research at the University of Birmingham focusing on ion-photon interfaces and cavity QED for quantum networks.

name: Brian McMahon
short_bio: Brian McMahon leads trapped-ion research at Georgia Tech focusing on quantum computing and quantum networks.

name: David J. Wineland
short_bio: David J. Wineland is a Nobel Laureate (2012) and pioneer of trapped-ion quantum computing. Currently at the University of Oregon after his foundational work at NIST Boulder.

name: Dietrich Leibfried
short_bio: Dietrich Leibfried leads the Ion Storage Group at NIST Boulder, continuing the foundational work on trapped-ion quantum computing and quantum logic spectroscopy.

name: David Hume
short_bio: David Hume leads the Aluminum Ion Clock project at NIST Boulder, developing the world's most precise optical atomic clock using quantum logic spectroscopy.

name: Christopher Monroe
short_bio: Christopher Monroe is a pioneer of trapped-ion quantum computing at the University of Maryland and JQI. Co-founder of IonQ, his group has demonstrated many landmark results in quantum computing and simulation.

name: Piet O. Schmidt
short_bio: Piet O. Schmidt leads trapped-ion optical clock research at PTB and Leibniz University Hannover, developing ultra-precise frequency standards using quantum logic spectroscopy.

name: Boris B. Blinov
short_bio: Boris B. Blinov leads the Trapped Ion Quantum Computing group at the University of Washington, focusing on barium ion quantum networks and ion-photon entanglement.

name: Tilman Esslinger
short_bio: Tilman Esslinger leads the Quantum Optics Group at ETH Zürich, known for ultracold atom experiments and increasingly exploring hybrid ion-atom systems.

name: Ferdinand Schmidt-Kaler
short_bio: Ferdinand Schmidt-Kaler leads the QUANTUM group at Universität Mainz, pioneering work on trapped-ion quantum computing, quantum simulation, and Rydberg excitation of ions.

name: Tracy E. Northup
short_bio: Tracy E. Northup leads the Quantum Interfaces group at the University of Innsbruck, focusing on cavity QED with trapped ions for quantum networks.

name: Ben P. Lanyon
short_bio: Ben P. Lanyon leads quantum networking research at the University of Innsbruck, demonstrating long-distance entanglement distribution with trapped calcium ions.

name: Jungsang Kim
short_bio:
Jungsang Kim is Chief Scientist at Quantinuum and Professor at Duke University. A pioneer in scalable trapped-ion quantum computing and integrated photonics for ion traps.
</Parameter>
